title: FC Argeș Pitești
text:
Asociația Clubul Sportiv Campionii Fotbal Club Argeș, commonly known as FC Argeș or Argeș Pitești (), is a Romanian professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="Club%20%28organization%29">club</a> based in the city of <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a>, <a href="Arge%C8%99%20County">Argeș County</a>, which competes in the <a href="Liga%20I">Liga I</a>.
The team was originally founded as "Dinamo Pitești" in 1953, and made its debut in the Romanian first division in <a href="1961%E2%80%9362%20Divizia%20A">1961</a>. In 1967, it was renamed Argeș Pitești. The most successful period of "the White-Violets" came in the <a href="1970s">1970s</a>, when they twice won the <a href="Liga%20I">national championship</a>. Three-time <a href="Romanian%20Footballer%20of%20the%20Year%20%28Gazeta%20Sporturilor%29">Romanian Footballer of the Year</a> award recipient <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Nicolae Dobrin</a> was part of the squad during that period, which turned him into a symbol of the club over the years.
FC Argeș has amassed over 40 seasons in the first league, and traditionally plays its home matches at the <a href="Stadionul%20Nicolae%20Dobrin">Nicolae Dobrin Stadium</a>, which has a capacity of 15,000 seats.
History.
Founding and early years (1953–1967).
On August 6, 1953, an order of the Ministry of Internal Affairs settled the birthday of "Dinamo Pitești", the current formation FC Argeș, the name being taken after the older sister from <a href="Bucharest">Bucharest</a>, <a href="FC%20Dinamo%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Dinamo București</a>. The new team from <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a> started its rise from the bottom, Campionatul Orășenesc, today <a href="Liga%20IV">Liga IV</a> or <a href="Liga%20V">Liga V</a>, but the involvement of the local administration in bringing the best football players from the city to FC Argeș will be the main factor in the consecutive promotions of the club. The promotion to <a href="Liga%20II">Divizia B</a> has occurred at the end of the 1958–1959 <a href="Liga%20III">Divizia C</a> season, and in the first year was very close to <a href="Liga%20I">Divizia A</a> promotion, but Dinamo occupied only the second place of the second series of <a href="Liga%20II">Divizia B</a>. The dream took shape for the football fans from <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a> in the next season. In 1961 Dinamo Pitești promoted on the first <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n football stage under the command of coaches Ştefan Vasile and Tănase Dima. Three of the most well-known members of the squad were <a href="Ion%20Barbu%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201938%29">Ion Barbu</a>, <a href="Florin%20Halagian">Florin Halagian</a> and <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Nicolae Dobrin</a>, the players who contributed the most at Dinamo's performance. <a href="1961%E2%80%9362%20Divizia%20A">1961–62 Divizia A</a> season was a tough one for the club which accused the shock of the debut and relegated back to <a href="Liga%20II">Divizia B</a> after only one year in the first league.
After only one season in <a href="Liga%20II">Divizia B</a>, Dinamo Pitești promoted again in 1963, remaining then a constant presence on the first stage of the <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n football, 10th place in <a href="1963%E2%80%9364%20Divizia%20A">1964</a>, but a season in which the team achieved <a href="Cupa%20Rom%C3%A2niei">Romanian Cup</a> final, 8th in <a href="1964%E2%80%9365%20Divizia%20A">1965</a>, 4th in <a href="1965%E2%80%9366%20Divizia%20A">1966</a> and 12th in <a href="1966%E2%80%9367%20Divizia%20A">1967</a>.
Golden era (1967–1983).
In the summer of 1967 the club changed its name from "Dinamo Pitești" to FC Argeș Pitești, a name that wrote history, remaining forever in the history of the <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n football and in the remembering of the fans.
The first season with the new name was a great one for FC Argeș, which finished 2nd, with the same number of points as <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Steaua București</a>, the champions of that season. The best ranking in club's history until then was followed only by a 12th place in <a href="1968%E2%80%9369%20Divizia%20A">1969</a>, a 10th place in <a href="1969%E2%80%9370%20Divizia%20A">1970</a> and a 9th place in <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20Divizia%20A">1971</a>.
Then in the <a href="1971%E2%80%9372%20Divizia%20A">1971–72 Divizia A</a> season nothing announced the great final success of "the White-Violets". In the first round the team had a bad debut, with a defeat (1–4) at <a href="FCM%20Bac%C4%83u">SC Bacău</a> and the tension within the team led to the dismissal of coach <a href="Titus%20Ozon">Titus Ozon</a>, in his place was promoted a young coach, <a href="Florin%20Halagian">Florin Halagian</a>, a former player of Dinamo Pitești. At his debut on August 29, 1971, being the youngest coach of <a href="Liga%20I">Divizia A</a>, FC Argeș won 2–1 against <a href="FC%20Rapid%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Rapid București</a>, both goals scored by <a href="Radu%20Jercan">Jercan</a>. At the end of the first part of the championship, FC Argeş was on the 4th place, with 18 points, following the teams: <a href="FC%20UTA%20Arad">UTA Arad</a>, <a href="FCM%20Bac%C4%83u">SC Bacău</a> and <a href="FC%20Universitatea%20Cluj">Universitatea Cluj</a>. The winter preparations took place at <a href="B%C4%83ile%20Herculane">Băile Herculane</a>, followed by a strong tournament in the former <a href="East%20Germany">East Germany</a>, tournament that would help the team a lot in the second part of the championship. The second part was extraordinary, FC Argeș being defeated only twice (0–2, at home against <a href="FC%20Bra%C8%99ov%20%281936%29">Steagul Roșu Brașov</a> and 0–1, at <a href="Cluj-Napoca">Cluj-Napoca</a>, against <a href="CFR%20Cluj">CFR</a>). There were followed by 9 games without defeats, in which <a href="Florin%20Halagian">Halagian</a> played the big card several times. Thus, in the match against <a href="FC%20Politehnica%20Ia%C8%99i%20%281945%29">Politehnica Iași</a>, he played in each half with a different line of midfielders, to everyone's surprise, to force the victory and to have fresh players until the end. In the penultimate stage (21 June 1972), at <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a>, FC Argeș defeated <a href="FC%20Bihor%20Oradea">Crişul Oradea</a>, becoming champion of <a href="Romania">Romania</a> for the first time in its history, with one round before the end of the championship. The team played very offensive and ambitious, with an inspired <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a> at the helm. The score was 4–1 (3–1) for "the White-Violets", through the goals scored by <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a> (min 25 and 43), <a href="Ion%20Prepurgel">Prepurgel</a> (min 28), <a href="Constantin%20Radu%20%28footballer%29">M. Joita</a> (min 83) and Tămaş for Crișul). In front of over 17,000 spectators, in the final round, although he had the title in his pocket, FC Argeș defeated <a href="FC%20Dinamo%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Dinamo București</a>, on <a href="Stadionul%20Na%C8%9Bional%20%281953%29">23 August Stadium</a>, with the score of 3–2, through the goals scored by: <a href="Radu%20Jercan">Jercan</a> (min 45), <a href="Constantin%20Radu%20%28footballer%29">C. Radu I</a> (min 55), <a href="Constantin%20Fr%C4%83%C8%9Bil%C4%83">Frățilă</a> (min 89), respectively <a href="Mircea%20Lucescu">Lucescu</a> (min 17) and <a href="Florea%20Dumitrache">Dumitrache</a> (min 61) for Dinamo.
Following their 1972 <a href="Liga%20I">Divizia A</a> title, FC Argeș played in <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">European Champion Clubs Cup</a>. In the first round, the team from <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a> eliminated without big problems, 6–0 on aggregate, <a href="FC%20Aris%20Bonnevoie">Aris Bonnevoie</a> from <a href="Luxembourg">Luxembourg</a>, but then in the second round fate have brought them in their way <a href="Real%20Madrid%20C.F.">Real Madrid</a>, a team with 6 <a href="UEFA%20Champions%20League">European Champion Clubs Cup</a>s at that moment and with big players like: <a href="Pirri">Pirri</a>, <a href="Ignacio%20Zoco">Ignacio Zoco</a>, <a href="Santillana%20%28footballer%29">Santillana</a> and <a href="Amancio%20Amaro">Amancio</a>, the coach was legendary <a href="Miguel%20Mu%C3%B1oz">Miguel Muñoz</a> and president was <a href="Santiago%20Bernab%C3%A9u%20Yeste">Santiago Bernabéu</a> himself. The match seemed to be a formality for <a href="Real%20Madrid%20C.F.">Real Madrid</a> but on the pitch FC Argeș made probably the best match in its entire history, a match in which a legend would be born, <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Nicolae Dobrin</a>. <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a> played absolutely fantastic wooing the audience and opponents, he scored for 1–0 in 24 minutes then Anzarda scored for 1–1 in 41 minutes. Prepurgel scored then for 2–1 in 62 minutes, goal followed by a multitude of occasions at the goal of the inspired <a href="Mariano%20Garc%C3%ADa%20Rem%C3%B3n">García Remón</a>. <a href="Santiago%20Bernab%C3%A9u%20Yeste">Santiago Bernabéu</a> amazed by <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a>'s technics offered 2 million dollars and a floodlight facility for him, but <a href="Nicolae%20Ceau%C8%99escu">Nicolae Ceaușescu</a> refused, considering <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a> a national treasure.
At <a href="Madrid">Madrid</a>, <a href="Real%20Madrid%20C.F.">Real</a> qualified hard after a goal scored in 87 minutes. The final score was 3–1, <a href="Santillana%20%28footballer%29">Santillana</a> (17', 87') and Grande (47') scored for Real, <a href="Marin%20Radu">Radu II</a> (43') for FC Argeș.
The following seasons were oscillating for the team which finished 3rd in <a href="1972%E2%80%9373%20Divizia%20A">1973</a>, 8th in <a href="1973%E2%80%9374%20Divizia%20A">1974</a>, 7th in <a href="1974%E2%80%9375%20Divizia%20A">1975</a> getting even to the 11th place in <a href="1975%E2%80%9376%20Divizia%20A">1976</a> and <a href="1976%E2%80%9377%20Divizia%20A">1977</a>.
Then in the <a href="1977%E2%80%9378%20Divizia%20A">1977–78 Divizia A</a> season FC Argeș had a remarkable comeback like the last time and finished 2nd, again at the same number of points with the leaders, <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Steaua București</a>, as in 1968.
<a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20Divizia%20A">1978–79 Divizia A</a> season started under the sign of a good training and a desire to fructify the growing maturity of a group of young players, most of them raised in <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a>. Under the leadership of the same coach, <a href="Florin%20Halagian">Florin Halagian</a>, helped by Leonte lanovschi and <a href="Constantin%20O%C5%A3et">Constantin Oţet</a>, transferred with a few days before the start of the championship. The goal of the club's leadership was to occupy one of the 1 to 5 places and to accumulate at least 18 points in the championship first part. FC Argeş started the championship in force, winning two games against <a href="Chimia%20R%C3%A2mnicu%20V%C3%A2lcea">Chimia Râmnicu Vâlcea</a> and <a href="FC%20Politehnica%20Ia%C8%99i%20%281945%29">Politehnica Iași</a> and ended up in the lead places. It was only in the 6th round when the club recorded the first defeat, 0–1, at <a href="T%C3%A2rgu%20Mure%C8%99">Târgu Mureș</a>, against <a href="ASA%20T%C3%A2rgu%20Mure%C8%99%20%281962%29">ASA Târgu Mureș</a>. The players were the subject of double efforts, most of them being part of the Romanian Olympic team, which managed, after many years, to defeat the Hungarian team at <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a>. At the end of the first part of the championship, FC Argeş was on the first position in the standings. A new player started successfully at <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a> team, <a href="Viorel%20Moiceanu">Moiceanu</a>, who soon became a secret weapon for the teammates and opponents. In the last round of the first part, FC Argeș won the match against <a href="FC%20Dinamo%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Dinamo București</a> (score 1–0) and became the champion of the first part with 10 matches won, a draw and 6 defeats, 25 goals scored and 17 received, totalizing 21 points, three more than the number proposed at the start of the championship.
The well-known sports journalist Laurențiu Dumitrescu wrote in "Sportul" newspaper, "... it was also in the autumn of 78 Dobrin's team, the team of that great talented player, who has been playing for more than 15 years with the 10 number shirt, the capable player – even at 31 years old – to decide any match in our championship (examples of testimonies: the matches against <a href="FC%20Baia%20Mare">FC Baia Mare</a>, on their own ground, and <a href="FC%20Steaua%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Steaua</a>, away) to score goals of great spectacularity. When <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a> was absent, intervened <a href="Sevastian%20Iov%C4%83nescu">Iovănescu</a>, an offensive midfielder who had an exceptional season, perhaps the best of his career, and he also took the role of puncher when the striker, <a href="Marin%20Radu">Radu II</a>, was injured. But was also <a href="Constantin%20Stancu">Stancu's</a> part of championship, who became at only 22 years old, the mature leader of the defense, defense which combines the experience of <a href="Petre%20Ivan%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201946%29">Ivan II</a> with <a href="Constantin%20C%C3%A2rstea">Cârstea</a>'s strength and the ambition of <a href="Mihai%20Zamfir%20%28footballer%29">Mihai Zamfir</a>."
On June 24, 1979, in front of 20,000 spectators, on the <a href="Stadionul%20Dinamo">Dinamo Stadium</a> in <a href="Bucharest">Bucharest</a>, FC Argeș defeated Dinamo, after a high-tension match, with the score 4–3, through the goals scored by: <a href="Marin%20Radu">Radu II</a> (min 11 and 24), <a href="Doru%20Nicolae">Doru Nicolae</a> (min 69) and <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a> (min 90) respectively <a href="Marin%20Dragnea">Dragnea</a> (min 6) and <a href="Dudu%20Georgescu">Dudu Georgescu</a> (min 76, from penalty, and min 89) and won the <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n title for the second time in its history.
After the game in "Sportul" newspaper, the well-known sports journalist <a href="Ioan%20Chiril%C4%83">Ioan Chirilă</a> wrote, "The championship final, expected with an extraordinary interest, which massively diminished the number of spectators on all the other grounds, ended with the deserved victory of the Pitești people after a high-tension game, in which the thirst for victory of Dinamo's players and supporters received a veto from <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a>, who offered to the audience and the viewers I do not know what number's game of his life, being the player who dominated the field from all points of view."
In <a href="1978%E2%80%9379%20UEFA%20Cup">1978–79 UEFA Cup</a> FC Argeș eliminated <a href="Panathinaikos%20F.C.">Panathinaikos</a> and gave up hard in front of <a href="Valencia%20CF">Valencia</a>, 4–6 on aggregate.
Than the club finished on the podium for 2 times, in <a href="1979%E2%80%9380%20Divizia%20A">1980</a> and <a href="1980%E2%80%9381%20Divizia%20A">1981</a> and only on 10th place <a href="1981%E2%80%9382%20Divizia%20A">1982</a>. Then in the summer of 1982 <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Nicolae Dobrin</a>, at 35 years old left FC Argeș for <a href="FCM%20T%C3%A2rgovi%C8%99te">CS Târgoviște</a> but the team didn't feel the shock too much and finished 4th in <a href="1982%E2%80%9383%20Divizia%20A">1983</a>. In the summer of 1983 Dobrin comeback to his big love, FC Argeș, but played only 5 matches and retired on 14 June 1983, in a match against <a href="FC%20Bihor%20Oradea">Bihor Oradea</a>, the team finishing in 5th place.
After Nicolae Dobrin (1983–2009).
The retirement of <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Nicolae Dobrin</a>, the emblematic symbol of FC Argeș, it also meant the end of the great performance for the club. In the 80's the team become a middle of the leaderboard team, finishing frequently on 6th, 7th or 9th place, but managed however to reach 3 <a href="Balkans%20Cup">Balkans Cup</a> finals in this period. Than at the end of the 80's and beginning of the 90's the team slipped even in the lower half everything cumulating with the relegation from <a href="Liga%20I">Divizia A</a> in <a href="1991%E2%80%9392%20Divizia%20A">1992</a> after 29 years spent in the top-flight of the <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n football.
Relegated in <a href="Liga%20II">Liga II</a> and with financial problems FC Argeș was taken over by <a href="Automobile%20Dacia">Dacia</a>, whose director was Constantin Stroe, who paid the debts. The club promoted back in 1994, finished 8th in <a href="1994%E2%80%9395%20Divizia%20A">1995</a> and was again at 5 points away from relegation in <a href="1995%E2%80%9396%20Divizia%20A">1996</a>. Than in the next season the team comeback in the middle of the table.
<a href="1997%E2%80%9398%20Divizia%20A">1997–98 Divizia A</a> season was the last peak of FC Argeș's history. The team finished 3rd and qualified for <a href="1998%E2%80%9399%20UEFA%20Cup">1998–99 UEFA Cup</a> where they eliminated teams like <a href="FC%20Baku">Dynamo Baku</a> and <a href="%C4%B0stanbulspor%20A.%C5%9E.">İstanbulspor</a> but were eliminated without problems by <a href="Celta%20de%20Vigo">Celta de Vigo</a> 0–8 on aggregate. This last presence in European Cups it was due to a formidable generation, the second most talented after the <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Dobrin</a>'s generation. This FC Argeș team had players like: <a href="Adrian%20Mutu">Adrian Mutu</a>, <a href="Bogdan%20Vintil%C4%83">Bogdan Vintilă</a>, <a href="Valentin%20N%C4%83stase">Valentin Năstase</a>, <a href="Iulian%20Crivac">Iulian Crivac</a>, <a href="Constantin%20Schumacher">Constantin Schumacher</a> or <a href="Constantin%20Barbu">Constantin Barbu</a>.
FC Argeș continued its good seasons finishing 4th in <a href="1998%E2%80%9399%20Divizia%20A">1999</a>, than on 5th place in <a href="1999%E2%80%932000%20Divizia%20A">2000</a> and <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20Divizia%20A">2001</a>. Than from <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20Divizia%20A">2002</a> the team was a constant presence in the second half of the leaderboard, finishing in the best case on 10th place. This bad period ended with the second relegation in the club's history, this time after 13 years, at the end of the <a href="2006%E2%80%9307%20Liga%20I">2006–07 Liga I</a> season.
The team promoted back after only one season in <a href="Liga%20II">Liga II</a>.
The "Romanian "Calciopoli"" and Bankruptcy (2009–2013).
"The White-Violet Eagles" finished 8th at their first season after the promotion, a season with good results and a solid style of playing. Than on June 8, 2009 a news would shock the world of the <a href="Romania">Romania</a>n football, FC Argeș was relegated in <a href="Liga%20II">Liga II</a>, after National Anti-corruption Division, found that the owner of the team from that period, Cornel Penescu, tried to bribe more referees to "help" the team winning. This case was named by the press "Penescu Case" or the "Romanian "<a href="2006%20Italian%20football%20scandal">Calciopoli</a>"".
After Cornel Penescu's arrest, his son, Andrei Penescu led the club, but the funding was practically non-existent and the club struggled to survive even in <a href="Liga%20II">Liga II</a>, finishing in the second half of the table. Then on July 26, 2013 it was announced that FC Argeș is <a href="Bankruptcy">bankrupt</a> without any chance of rescue.
SCM Pitești and supporters' club (2013–2017).
After the bankruptcy of FC Argeș, people of <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a> have tried to bring football back to life.
The first project was <a href="SCM%20Pite%C8%99ti">SCM Pitești</a>, a project initiated by Pitești Municipality which created a football section at SCM, the Sporting Club of the Municipality, in 2011, with 2 years before the end of FC Argeș, anticipating the bankruptcy of the club led at that time by Penescu's son, a club full of debts and with no future. The team promoted at <a href="Liga%20III">Liga III</a> after only one season and remained at that level until 2017 when they promoted to <a href="Liga%20II">Liga II</a>.
The supporters of FC Argeș encouraged the team until the very end, then after the bankruptcy they founded <a href="FC%20Arge%C8%99%201953%20Pite%C5%9Fti">FC Argeș 1953 Piteşti</a>, a <a href="Phoenix%20club%20%28sports%29">phoenix club</a> fully owned by FC Argeș supporters. The club won <a href="2015%E2%80%9316%20Liga%20IV">2015–16 Liga IV</a>-<a href="Arge%C8%99%20County">Argeș County</a> and than the promotion play-off match against Recolta Stoicănești, <a href="Olt%20County">Olt County</a> champion, with the score of 5–2, but they couldn't join <a href="Liga%20III">Liga III</a> due to lack of funds and then dissolved the senior team.
Then Pitești Municipality has shown the intention to buy FC Argeș's brand and the fans have also announced that they support this initiative.
Rebirth and return to Liga I (2017–present).
On 16 June 2017, the Municipality of Pitești bought FC Argeș's brand for 550,000 <a href="Romanian%20leu">RON</a>. As a result of this association, the brand was transferred to SCM Pitești's football section, newly promoted to the <a href="Liga%20II">second division</a>, and the team came back to life four years after it was declared bankrupt. After promotion, the team spent 3 years in the second league. FC Argeș managed to earn promotion to the first division at the end of the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20Liga%20II">2019–20 season</a>, after an 11-year break. Pitești narrowly earned a 2nd place, after <a href="FC%20Rapid%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Rapid</a> held <a href="Turris-Oltul%20Turnu%20M%C4%83gurele">Turris-Oltul Turnu Măgurele</a> to a draw in the seventh minute of extra time, a score at which Teleorman remained in the second league, and FC Argeș promoted directly.
In the first half of their <a href="2020%E2%80%9321%20Liga%20I">comeback season</a>, FC Argeș failed to impress, their winless streak leaving them last place in the league at the beginning of 2021. Things began to change after former player <a href="Andrei%20Prepeli%C8%9B%C4%83">Andrei Prepeliță</a> took over as manager, the team recording a 11 unbeaten league games run, and slowly crawling out of the relegation places to join the fight for a play-off place. With their unbeaten streak cut short by a 0–5 defeat against reigning champions <a href="CFR%20Cluj">CFR Cluj</a>, FC Argeș kept their momentum, but never made it above 7th place. They missed a chance to make it through with a 1–1 draw against fellow play-off contenders <a href="FC%20Academica%20Clinceni">Academica Clinceni</a> and by the penultimate round, they missed the play-off qualification altogether following a 1–4 loss against <a href="FC%20Hermannstadt">Hermannstadt</a>.
Youth program.
Youth academy of FC Argeș gave important names for Romanian and international football like: <a href="Nicolae%20Dobrin">Nicolae Dobrin</a>, <a href="Adrian%20Mutu">Adrian Mutu</a>, <a href="Ilie%20B%C4%83rbulescu%20%28footballer%29">Ilie Bărbulescu</a>, <a href="Marius%20Bila%C8%99co">Marius Bilașco</a>, <a href="Constantin%20C%C3%A2rstea">Constantin Cârstea</a>, <a href="D%C4%83nu%C8%9B%20Coman">Dănuț Coman</a>, <a href="Iulian%20Crivac">Iulian Crivac</a>, <a href="Emil%20Dic%C4%83">Emil Dică</a>, <a href="Valentin%20N%C4%83stase">Valentin Năstase</a>, <a href="Adrian%20Neaga">Adrian Neaga</a>, <a href="Marin%20Radu">Marin Radu</a>, <a href="Bogdan%20Stancu">Bogdan Stancu</a>, <a href="Cristian%20T%C4%83nase">Cristian Tănase</a>, <a href="Constantin%20Stancu">Constantin Stancu</a>, <a href="Bogdan%20Vintil%C4%83">Bogdan Vintilă</a> and <a href="Ion%20Vl%C4%83doiu">Ion Vlădoiu</a>.
Stadium.
The club played its home matches on <a href="Stadionul%20Nicolae%20Dobrin">Stadionul Nicolae Dobrin</a> from <a href="Pite%C8%99ti">Pitești</a>, a stadium with a capacity of 15,000 seats, the biggest of <a href="Arge%C8%99%20County">Argeș County</a>.
Support.
FC Argeș has many supporters in <a href="Romania">Romania</a> and especially in <a href="Arge%C8%99%20County">Argeș County</a>. The ultras groups of FC Argeș are known as "Violet Republic", "Brigada Vulturii București" and "Frați de weeknd".
Rivalries.
FC Argeș does not have any important rivalries, but one of them is with <a href="FC%20Dinamo%20Bucure%C8%99ti">Dinamo București</a> and the other one is a local one against <a href="CS%20Mioveni">CS Mioveni</a>, with the town of <a href="Mioveni">Mioveni</a> being located at only 15 kilometres away from Pitești.
